div1.p: Carter discusses his work, and influenza.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, October 7, 1918
div1.p:
I am purposing to leave for
Baltimore tomorrow-morning
If I do I will probably not send
this letter. Will hold it toward
the end of the day:

I went to R'd & Ashland Saturday
afternoon & stayed there to this
morning leaving at c
7.30. Train due at 6.40
& I waited that long for it,
- C.E. 55 minutes.

Have just got in Petersburg
& find Philps- the engineer
is
2
is sick with influenza & what
I can find out about Clark coming
up from N. News to run some
level lines I can till what I
Canwill do about leaving

L'lucky enough I will have to re-
main a few days & put
the gangs of men to work
so as to get them started. Prac-
tically nothing has been
done in Black water swamp
as yet. If so I will have a -
3
about Friday or Saturday - the
latter probably

In the meantime I don't think
I have been exposed to the In-
fluenza so far- at least not
directly - & I am going to
do what I can to avoid expos
such exposure.

The reason why I wired to
hold the mail was be-
cause I expected to come
home sunday en.

I have received one but
4
about the end of this week,
In the meantime I don't
think I have been exposed
to the influenza - at least
not directly. & I am going
to do what I can to avoid such
exposure.

I received a batch of mail
just as I started for R'd - a-
mong them your letter-
I haven't had time to attend
to any of it. The reason I
wired to hold my mail
was
5
was because I had purposed to
leave Petersburg yesterday
morning & get home that af-
ternoon. Best hold what
you have - unless I notify
you to the contrary - as I still
hope to leave Wednesday. If
I decide to the contrary will
wire you to send it.

Will f mail this now as
I fear when I return from
Blackwater. it will be too late
for this afternoon's mail
6
If I wire for my mail it
means that I stay here until
- say f say - Friday or Satur-
day - you can tell by the
date “up to” which I ask
it to be sent - I will not leave
Petersburg for 24 hours thereafter any
way.

Oh, I have a sample of O.D. whip-
cord for w'h I can get a uniform
made for $45-' I can ge made
7
in Balt. (English Woolen
Mills - Tailors of no reputation
but who made a good suit
for me when I went abroad.).

Also I bought an rain coat
- rather common - but double
over the shoulders - $3.85/100 from
Q, masters, Can get a rough
(Privates) uniform for a-
bout $7.006.80. & can have it
altered to fit - for about $3.20 but
(Griffitts
8
(Griffits did so)- but the pockets
willwould be extra- Have sample of the
whipcord & address in Balt, of
the men who would make it- It
can be either light or heavy - price the
same- The other material is
nearly the same as my overcoat
I am taking care of my self,
both in trying to keep up my
strength & avoiding infection
In this both you & Mary take
me for a model.
Love to the P. W. & Mary.
